description:
Macaca silenus, commonly known as the lion-tailed macaque, is a species of Old World monkey endemic to the Western Ghats region of India. It is a medium-sized primate with a distinctive appearance, characterized by its long, silver-gray fur and black face surrounded by a mane-like ruff of long hair.

The lion-tailed macaque is an arboreal species, spending most of its time in the upper canopy of tropical evergreen and semi-evergreen forests. It is an omnivorous primate, feeding on a variety of plant materials, fruits, seeds, flowers, and insects. The species is known for its complex social structure, living in multi-male, multi-female groups with a clear dominance hierarchy.

Macaca silenus is classified as Endangered on the IUCN Red List of Threatened Species due to habitat loss, fragmentation, and poaching. Conservation efforts are underway to protect this unique primate and its remaining habitat in the Western Ghats.
